Update: I asked Peter Bentley if it would be all right to upload the
video to Google Video, and he said yes, as long as I linked back to
his site and didn't edit it in any way. I didn't see a reason why it
shouldn't be available as streaming video, since it's the venues exist
and it's a pain to download the torrent. Anyway, the link is here:

http://video.google.com/videoplay?docid=3201752343509862659&hl=en

Ken's question is at 59:21 in the video.

On Jan 2, 2008 12:58 AM, Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Derek, I had forgotten that they recorded that debate. I enjoyed
>  having the opportunity to ask my question to such illustrious
>  scientists, but like you, I was kind of disappointed with their
>  answers. Like you said, they sort of answered accurately, but there
>  was no real insight or thoughtfulness in what they said.
>
>  It's interesting that you point out this exchange because I think it
>  highlights a weakness in how biologists have been dealing with the
>  question of complexity. It's such a fundamental question yet it
>  hasn't really received the treatment it deserves, even from the
>  field's luminaries. I think part of the problem is that a genuine
>  treatment requires a kind of algorithmic and representational theory,
>  which is perhaps better attacked from a computational perspective,
>  putting evolutionary computation researchers at an advantage because
>  we think about search spaces, encodings, mappings, etc. routinely.

Yes, I think you're right that EC researcher probably come at the
problem from an angle that might be more productive, but I'm
especially disappointed in Wolpert, who was the main voice for
developmental biology on the panel. Your question gets to issues that
a developmental biologist should primarily be interested in.

Even if he didn't have specific insights related to the development of
the human brain, he should have been able to give other examples with
which he was more familiar.

By the way, I recently read Pasko Rakic's 1995 paper "A small step for
the cell, a giant leap for mankind: a hypothesis of neocortical
expansion during evolution" from Trends in Neuroscience:

http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6T0V-3Y6PFXS-1P&_user=10&_rdoc=1&_fmt=&_orig=search&_sort=d&view=c&_acct=C000050221&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=4eba37dec70f1bb0d9022402f97aee43

Here's the abstract:

The more than 1000-fold increase in the cortical surface without a
comparable increase in its thickness during mammalian evolution is
explained in the context of the radial-unit hypothesis of cortical
development. According to the proposed model, cortical expansion is
the result of changes in proliferation kinetics that increase the
number of radial columnar units without changing the number of neurons
within each unit significantly. Thus, mutation of a regulatory gene(s)
that controls the timing and ratio of symmetric and asymmetric modes
of cell divisions in the proliferative zone, coupled with radial
constraints in the distribution of migrating neurons, could create an
expanded cortical plate with enhanced capacity for establishing new
patterns of connectivity that are validated through natural selection.

I'm personally working under the assumption that the cortical
minicolumn is the primary module, that repeatable bit of code that
Dawkins talked about, and there are a number of good work by
biologists out there, including Rakic, who give support to such an
idea.

>  Perhaps they were just being curt or did not take the audience
>  seriously enough to elaborate their thoughts. Yet I find that
>  explanation doubtful given that we were after all at a "debate" about
>  evolution and complexity, which is precisely the substance of my
>  question. I also agree that Dawkins seemed closest to really
>  thinking about it, so I'd guess Dawkins would be very interested in
>  our area of EC if only there was an opportunity to tell him about
>  it. But I don't think he has a great deal of experience with it
>  beyond his old Blind Watchmaker demo.

I guess you didn't have a chance to corner him and talk things over?
:) Dawkins does seem like he would be interested in a lot of the work
being presented at GECCO. Did he just show up for the panel, or was he
around the conference at all?

I was also thought the other really interesting exchange was at 33:45
in the video, when the question of whether or not you could evolve a
mouse with feathered wings came up, and Wolpert and Jones both said
no, while Dawkins seemed to say probably not, but not for any of the
reasons the other guys came up with.

--Derek
